content:
I’m a data scientist and PhD candidate in Geoscience who specializes in using data assimilation techniques to reconstruct past climates. My research focuses on combining natural climate archives, like tree-rings and ice-cores, with general circulation climate models. I also teach data science skills workshops for The Carpentries and the University of Arizona to help promote open, reproducible science.
  Download my CV or scroll for more information.
summary: I’m a data scientist and PhD candidate in Geoscience who specializes in using data assimilation techniques to reconstruct past climates. My research focuses on combining natural climate archives, like tree-rings and ice-cores, with general circulation climate models.
title: Jonathan King

summary: Workshops on many data science tools including Python, git, Bash, and more.
title: Resbaz 2021

content: We’re reconstructing the Southern Annular Mode (SAM) over the Common Era by applying data assimilation to drought atlases and the PAGES network of temperature sensitive climate proxies. The SAM is a major influence on Southern Hemisphere climate, and has impacts on storm tracks, drought, and ice melt. Understanding its past variations can help characterize its behavior and predict its response to future climate change.
summary: Reconstructing the SAM by assimilating drought atlases and PAGES.
title: Assimilating the Southern Annular Mode

content: We’re using data assimilation to constrain climate reconstructions of the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM). Check out Jess Tierney’s paper, which uses reconstructed SSTs at the LGM to constrain ECS, and Matt Osman’s new reconstruction of surface temperatures from the LGM to present.
summary: Assimilating climate from the Last Glacial Maximum to present.
title: LGM Reconstructions

content: In December 2019, I helped with a Tasmanian tree-ring sampling effort led by Kathy Allen on the slopes of Mt. Wylly. We sampled a mix of live and dead trees, but were particularly searching for fossil wood records to help extend tree ring chronologies over the last several millennia. These tree ring records can help reconstruct regional climate effects and the Southern Annular Mode.
summary: Collecting Tasmanian tree ring records.
title: Mt. Wylly Collection

content: We’re using data assimilation to examine the sensitivity of the climate system to volcanic eruptions throughout the Common Era. Check out Feng Zhu’s recent papers probing discrepancies between reconstructions and models and testing the ENSO response to volcanism.
summary: Probing climate sensitivity to volcanism using data assimilation.
title: Volcanic Assimilations

content: DASH is a Matlab package that facilitates paleoclimate data assimilation workflows. It includes utilities to build and organize state vectors, estimate proxy values using proxy system models (PSMs), and implement Ensemble Kalman Filters, Particle Filters, and Optimal Sensor tests. It has been used to implement a number of recent scientific studies.
summary: A Matlab package for paleoclimate data assimilation workflow.
title: DASH

content: This workshop is designed to introduce scientists and academic reseachers to the Github platform. It covers fundamental git concepts (such as cloning, pushing, and branches), and provides demos showing how to implement common tasks using Github Desktop and the online Github website. This tutorial was a product of the Digital Scholarship and Data Science Fellowship at the University of Arizona.
summary: An introduction to Github for scientists and academic researchers.
title: Github Workshop

content: I’m an instructor for Research Bazaar (Resbaz) 2021 at the University of Arizona. Resbaz is a week-long series of workshops teaching data science skills. Topics include starting with Python, R, git, Bash, Latex, and more. If you’re interested in attending, follow this link to see the schedule and register.
summary: Workshops on data science tools including Python, git, Bash, and more.
title: Research Bazaar 2021

content: I’m a data science ambassador for the College of Science at the University of Arizona. If you are a member of the CoS and are looking for resources or help implementing data science for your research, please get in touch! For more information about the Data Science Ambassadors program, check out the DSA Website.
summary: Providing data science assistance for the UA College of Science.
title: Data Science Ambassador

content: We’re reconstructing surface temperatures in the Northern Hemisphere over the last millennium using data assimilation. This project focuses on the NTREND network, an expert-curated selection of temperature-sensitive tree ring records.
summary: Reconstructing Northern Hemisphere temperatures using NTREND.
title: NTREND Assimilation

summary: An introduction to Github for scientists and academic researchers.
title: Github Workshop

summary: Assimilating sea surface temperature proxies over the Last Glacial Maximum constrains equilibrium climate sensitivity.
title: Glacial cooling and climate sensitivity revisited

summary: Assimilating tree-ring records helps resolve discrepancies between simulated and reconstructed climate reponse to volcanism.
title: Resolving the differences in the simulated and reconstructed climate response to volcanism over the last millennium

summary: A sensitivity analysis of calculated reservoir temperatures in Yellowstone.
title: Multireaction equilibrium geothermometry: A sensitivity analysis using data from the Lower Geyser Basin, Yellowstone National Park, USA

summary: We synthesize and characterize zinc sulfide nanotubes.
title: Direct growth by arc discharge and computational study of zinc sulfide nanotubes

summary: A characterization of cadmium-sulfide nanostructures.
title: Properties of transition metal doped cadmium sulfide hexamers and dodecamers

summary: We reconstruct Nothern Hemisphere temperatures over the last millennium by assimilating a highly-sensitive, curated tree-ring network.
title: A data assimilation approach to last millennium temperature field reconstruction using a limited high-sensitivity proxy network

summary: We reconstruct surface temperatures since the Last Glacial Maximum using data assimilation.
title: Globally resolved surface temperatures since the Last Glacial Maximum

summary: We use data assimilation to probe the links between ENSO and volcanism.
title: Volcanoes and ENSO: a re-appraisal with the Last Millennium Reanalysis
